techniques.name: XRD
techniques.parameters: Bragg–Brentano geometry, graphite monochromator, Cu Kα radiation

challenge.description: Irreversible decomposition of the spinel phase occurs between 600°C and 800°C under N2 flow.
challenge.impact: This decomposition leads to the formation of Mn3O4 and orthorhombic LiMnO2 phases, which compromises the stability and integrity of the spinel structure.

solution.description: The authors suggest controlling the oxygen partial pressure during synthesis to stabilize the spinel phase.
solution.methodology: Using air or O2 atmospheres instead of N2 during thermal treatments.
solution.effectiveness: The spinel phase was found to be stable up to 980°C in air or O2 atmospheres, demonstrating the effectiveness of this approach.

evidence.data: XRD patterns show the spinel phase is stable up to 980°C in air or O2, while decomposition occurs under N2.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with reversible ionic distribution at high temperatures.
context.experimental_conditions: Thermal treatments under different atmospheres (air, O2, N2) and temperatures up to 1050°C.
context.application_relevance: Stability of the spinel phase is critical for its use in rechargeable lithium-ion batteries and catalytic applications.

challenge.description: Difficulty in achieving satisfactory fits using the inverse spinel model for quenched samples.
challenge.impact: This issue complicates the accurate determination of cation distribution and structural properties of the material.

solution.description: The authors used a modified cubic spinel model to account for cation displacement and lithium migration.
solution.methodology: Rietveld refinement with a modified cubic spinel model assuming partial occupancy of Mn at the 8a site and Li at the interstitial 16c site.
solution.effectiveness: Satisfactory refinement results were obtained with χ² values between 1.30 and 1.56, and Rwp values between 22.5% and 26.2%.

evidence.data: Rietveld refinement results show improved fits with the modified cubic spinel model.

context.material_properties: Cubic spinel structure with reversible cation distribution changes at high temperatures.
context.experimental_conditions: High-temperature XRD measurements and Rietveld refinement analysis.
context.application_relevance: Accurate structural characterization is essential for understanding the material's performance in electrochemical and catalytic applications.

challenge.description: Oxygen release during high-temperature treatments leads to changes in cation distribution and oxidation states.
challenge.impact: This affects the charge balance and stability of the spinel structure, potentially reducing its performance in applications like lithium-ion batteries.

solution.description: The authors propose a reversible model where lithium ions occupy interstitial sites to maintain charge balance.
solution.methodology: Thermal cycling experiments under controlled oxygen partial pressures to study reversible cation distribution changes.
solution.effectiveness: The spinel phase was preserved with a 1:2 Li/Mn ratio after thermal cycling, confirming the reversibility of the process.

evidence.data: TG measurements and XRD patterns confirm reversible oxygen uptake and cation redistribution upon cooling.

context.material_properties: Spinel structure with reversible ionic distribution and oxygen release/uptake.
context.experimental_conditions: Thermal cycling in air or O2 atmospheres with temperatures up to 980°C.
context.application_relevance: Reversible cation distribution and oxygen uptake are critical for maintaining the material's electrochemical performance.
